Just like 1 o’clock is experienced or perceived chronologically as before, earlier or first, compared to 2 o clock.
Forward and back must have a connotation that defines them chronologically. When you are thinking only of yourself in time, reference being your memory of things chronologically, “back” is behind you. Like “remember back then. But it can only define any number of infinite moments before “now”. And “moving forward” cannot define a specific moment on its own either, only any and all moments following this one. Unless specified.

But if you think of an abstract meeting as yourself and move it based on if you were in it, you would again think “back” means before it’s destined moment. And forward means after.

But a meeting is not a living thing, and cannot perceive time as past or present in relation to itself because it only exists for a moment.

Until it is happening it is always in the future, once it passes it is forever in the past. Unlike humans, who exist now, as well as having a history. And as far as we know, we exist in the foreseeable future as well unless we suddenly die.

Therefore you can’t ascribe a perspective to an abstract like a meeting, because the meeting itself does not think for itself. You must think for it in your own perspective as must the other invitees, in order to conceptualize when to attend it. Which is what we use clocks and schedules for. A clock has no end. It simply moves “forward with time” or clockwise as we perceive it. But if you had to go “back in time” the clock would have to go counter clockwise as you perceive it. So you have gone back in time.

But the meeting cannot perceive time. It is where ever we want it to be and is not bound to continuity until it has happened. It moves in relation to those who perceive it being us. As the meeting gets closer, it moves “up” in priority, it moves “forward” from the perspective of those who perceive it as near or far chronologically. That is us.

To move something back in relation to yourself is like shuffling cards and putting one in the back of the deck, meaning that chronologically, you will pull that card last because you placed the others in front of it. If you move “up” in a line or queue, you have gotten closer to the action point. If you go to the “back of the line, you are at the end and will be served last.

In English, “back” is a negative and forward is a positive. In relation to what is important: perspective, back is further away, and so as we approach something in time, if it moves “back”, it’s imperative is to get “further” away from a point where it is perceived. Only organisms can perceive, so the point is imperatively our present.

The reason why we are moving toward it and it is not getting closer to us is because I’m physics, movement is defined by perspective on a line or plane.

If something that is defined and doesn’t usually move like an event, is what is moving then it implies that we are stationary or moving towards it to meet it. We perceive time as linear and exist for a Stretch of time.

An event is but a point from our perspective. Such that in all of time which certainly exists, we are but a point in its infinite stretch. A point does not grow or stretch once it has ended, so from our perspective as a line, the point must approach us, pass through us as it is perceived, and then leave us for the past, no longer perceptible to the present except in memory.

Just like if we were moving through the 1rst dimension. An object gets bigger as it gets closer, then shrinks into nothingness after it passes out of perspective which is also our event horizon. It came forward because it was approaching. It went back as we watched it leave us.

The language neccesitates this meaning. There would be no point of “forward” or back if you and I were equal to time it’self and a 20 minute meeting. That suggests you, me, the meeting, and time itself are all privileged chess pieces on a board.

But in reality, the way we understand time, physics and perspective, means that events are squares, clear and defined, you and I are pawns moving forwards and never back wards according to the rules of the game (laws of the universe) and the board is time itself. Existing indefinitely through every player and countless games.

When you move the clocks forward, the time you are currently at shifts closer/earlier, just like the meeting. Example: the clocks go forward at 2am, thus meaning that 2am becomes 3am, therefore 3am has happend 1 hour sooner / 1 hour earlier.

If you have a meeting that happens in 10 hours in the future and you move the clocks forward then that meeting will be 9 hours in the future, therefore it is 1 hour earlier than it otherwise would have been.

When the clocks go forward you lose an hour - everything is brought closer by 1 hour to you. When the clocks go back you insert an extra hour in, therefore moving everything 1 hour further away from you / moving everything 1 hour later than what it would otherwise be.

This is perfectly consistent. Universally the definition of moving something forward is to make it happen sooner, and moving something back is making it happen later. I can see how one could deconstruct the language and question the semantics behind who or what is moving where if you enjoy wordplay etc, and I can understand how it might be confusing to a non native speaker, but outside of academic or philosophical discussion the accepted definition of moving something forward is to bring it closer/move it earlier/make it happen sooner, as opposed to saying that one could push a deadline back later in the day.

On the other hand, you could be saying "the meeting is now 2 hours earlier, that is, it's time was forwarded 2 hours, we got to the meeting earlier, because we forwarded time".

The more effective way to communicate either or is to say "the meeting was postponed/advanced 2 hours". Even so, what's being forwarded semantically at least is the meeting - not the time agreed for the meeting -, which has a closer to natural interpretation of postponing and not advancing.
